perturbation.changed_text:
The BSP then have the option to renew the agreement for another 5 years subject to any restructuring of the agreement as required by the parties.

Either party may advise the other of the impending expiry of the then current term, generally in accordance with section 14. However, Datec may only renew the contract one time, while BSP has unlimited renewals .
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction regarding the renewal terms. Originally, both parties could advise on expiry. Now, Datec is limited to one renewal, while BSP has unlimited, creating uncertainty and conflicting obligations regarding renewal rights.

perturbation.changed_text:
The maximum rebate in any given month will be 50% of the monthly base fee. The rebate calculation will be completed before the 15th Day of the following month for the preceding month together with supporting monthly reports and provided to the BSP.

For the purposes of determining SLA achievement the "Time to Resolve" measurement will be used, but may be superseded by 'Time to Respond' depending on which metric is more favorable to Datec.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates ambiguity in SLA measurement. Initially, 'Time to Respond' was the metric. Now, Datec has the option to choose either 'Time to Resolve' or 'Time to Respond' depending on which is more favorable, introducing a clear conflict of interest and making enforcement of SLA unreliable.

This alteration introduces a contradiction about service levels during disengagement. Originally, there was to be no degradation of service, and all SLAs applied, now there will be a 50% degradation of services and the SLAs do not apply. Also Datec can change the plan without approval creating conflict and uncertainty about the expected quality and terms of disengagement.
